Description: Body sherd of Chian Simple Animal Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: glazed streaky black (fired yellowish brown) with traces of single band in added white; exterior: painted decoration consisting of seated sphinx (part of belly and hind leg remaining), to left; below, pair of narrow glaze (fired brown) bands; below, in handle zone, double saw-edged metope pattern; at right, group of five vertical strokes; part of ancient repair hole on right edge of sherd.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Ure Museum of Greek Archaeology, Reading. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lions are usually depicted on Chalice style chalices seated facing right whilst sphinxes are seated facing left. Although Lemos does not specifically list this sherd in her fourth stage of the Group of the Simple Figures, the poor quality of the image on the exterior surface fits this grouping quite well. Figures portrayed on vases from this stage are poorly executed. Rim patterns and handle zones are disorderly. For parallels regarding the body shape and handle zone pattern, see Cambridge Museum of Classical Archaeology NA77. The Ure Museum received sherds from the Egypt Exploration Society (EES) in 1926, several years after Petrie and Gardner's excavations. It was uncertain then whether the sherds came from Naukratis or Tell Dafana, a site in the eastern Nile Delta that was excavated by Petrie in 1886. Petrie wrote that he found only one sherd of Chian ware at Tell Dafana (Petrie 1888 62), which he described as a plain piece, thus the Chian sherds in the Reading collection come from Naukratis.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 292, no. 912, pl. 121)
CVA Reading I / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain, Fasc. 12, University of Reading (p. 37, pl. 23, no. 4a-b)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1214) (phase 2)
